awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Class Bucks Engagement and Gamified Learning System
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is in the positive effect it will have in the classroom, and ultimately, on school dropouts. Dropouts face bleak economic futures, are more likely to commit a crime and be incarcerated, suffer poor health, and exact a financial toll on society. Since dropping out of school is a gradual process of a student becoming disengaged in the classroom, the proposed project will address school dropout at the most elemental level. At the end of this project, the development team will have an innovative, web-based game that will transform the classroom dynamic, in any school, and give teachers meaningful analytics so they can better meet their student’s needs, keep them engaged in the learning process, and reduce the number of kids dropping out of school. The innovative platform has the potential raise the learning opportunities for marginalized learners and stimulate positive societal change.


The intellectual merit of this project is in the quantitative measurement and tracking of student engagement and production of a longitudinal analysis for each student, so teachers can track engagement throughout an entire quarter, semester, or year.  The solution will empower instructors to make more well-informed decisions for their classrooms. The research will focus on converting the original composite, laborious, pen, paper, and spreadsheet version of the tool into a web-based version that integrates with teacher lessons while accommodating diverse content areas and a multitude of teaching styles. As students interact with the web-based, gamified lesson delivery platform, they can earn or lose virtual dollars while learning valuable soft skills such as such as responsibility, critical thinking, and work ethics, including financial literacy skills such as online banking, investing, using credit, and budgeting. This project will harness the game platform quality to capture students' attention and generate motivation to invest time and energy into learning. In the process, the game will collect valuable learning metrics and provide reports and analytics for teachers so they can learn more about their students. The goal of the proposed project is to develop the minimum viable product and test pilot its efficacy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Class Bucks is an innovative game-based learning management platform developed to combat widespread student disengagement--a leading indicator of academic underperformance and dropout risk, particularly in underserved communities. Despite its importance, engagement is rarely measured objectively and accurately in real time. Class Bucks fills this gap by providing a tool for teachers to track student attentiveness and comprehension during instruction, while motivating students through a virtual classroom economy.

The Class Bucks team--composed of current career educators with over 85 years of combined experience in classrooms and school leadership--developed the platform in response to a growing national crisis: student disengagement. Research shows that 65% of high school students report feeling disengaged in school, making disengagement one of the strongest early warning signs for future dropout risk. Class Bucks was created as a direct response to this challenge.

The platform introduces randomized Engagement Stimuli (EStims) and teacher-initiated Check-for-Understanding (CFU) prompts during lessons. These mechanisms measure attentiveness (response time) and cognitive awareness (response accuracy), producing actionable data for teachers and incentives for students. Students earn "Class Bucks" for timely and correct participation, which they can spend in a class-based marketplace.

During Phase I, the team developed a functional prototype of the Class Bucks platform, including the teacher dashboard, student interface, and data reporting tools. The platform was tested with eight secondary teachers and over 200 students across multiple classrooms. More than 130 customer discovery interviews with educators, administrators, and financial literacy leaders (building on 180 previous interviews from the NSF I-Corps program) helped shape the product and validate market demand.

A key technical achievement during Phase I was the validation of a novel engagement measurement framework. By capturing both attentiveness and comprehension in real time, Class Bucks offers a dual-layered view of engagement that has not previously been available in typical K-12 classrooms. This non-disruptive method allows engagement data to be gathered during live instruction without requiring specialized equipment or assessments.

Results from user testing were highly encouraging:

  • 90.3% of students reported enjoying Class Bucks 
  • 80.6% said it helped them stay engaged 
  • 71.0% said it improved their ability to learn and retain content

Teachers observed improved student participation, focus, and responsiveness. Class Bucks enabled them to adapt instruction in real time, re-teach concepts, and target support to students in need. Teachers also used end-of-lesson engagement data to inform future planning and identify students requiring additional intervention.

The platform was designed to function seamlessly across traditional, online, hybrid, and flipped classroom models, and is compatible with both mobile and laptop devices. Key refinements during the user testing and iterative design phase of the Phase I project included simplifying the user interface, expanding gamification features, and developing online teacher training modules to replace time-intensive, in-person sessions.

Class Bucks also supports broader educational equity. By making student engagement visible and measurable for every learner, teachers can identify and support students who might otherwise be overlooked. Because it functions across diverse classroom models and device access levels, Class Bucks is well-positioned to serve schools with limited resources. Its design is centered on equity--providing educators with tools to reach all students and offering low-stakes, high-frequency opportunities for learners to engage, succeed, and be recognized.

The use of game-based rewards and a classroom economy engages students who may not respond to traditional instructional strategies, while simultaneously reinforcing foundational financial literacy skills.

Preliminary findings also suggest a correlation between student engagement data and indicators of social-emotional well-being. These insights open avenues for future research on how classroom behavior and engagement data may support broader student wellness and mental health strategies.

Challenges during Phase I included delays resulting from staffing changes at the partnering development firm and difficulty scheduling in-person trainings with teacher participants. These were addressed by shifting to a smaller, iterative testing model and developing asynchronous training resources. Teacher feedback also led to several feature improvements, including enhanced device accessibility, expanded lesson modes (e.g., discussion and asynchronous), and improved automated reporting for both students and classes.

The Class Bucks team has generated a range of ideas to enhance the platform's effectiveness, accessibility, and classroom impact. These future developments aim to better support teachers, engage students, and strengthen the platform's commercial readiness. By the conclusion of Phase II, Class Bucks aspires to be a fully operational, scalable solution that improves learning outcomes, boosts classroom participation, and supports equitable instruction across diverse educational settings.
